channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: The Supreme Court reinstated the death sentence for Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. An appeals court set aside the sentence after finding trial errors that might have prejudiced the jury (corrects now-deleted tweet that misspelled his first name) https://t.co/mbmOySiN5C
Ukrainian and international food manufacturers, distributors and aid workers are scrambling to keep grocery stores and pharmacies open, and shelves stocked https://t.co/RytxnperB2

Weapons from the West have made make a big difference, as have the Russians’ Soviet-style tactics, Ukrainian officers say. “We go out to hunt and destroy them,” says one Ukranian special-forces team leader on Kyiv’s front lines. https://t.co/NZgwXD6qQJ

Hundreds of thousands of Ukrainian technology workers have taken part in cyberattacks against Russia’s government, media and financial institutions in recent days, a top Ukrainian cybersecurity official said Friday https://t.co/SENFMAZuOh

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R., S.C.) doubled down Friday on his call for the Russian people to assassinate or overthrow Russian President Vladimir Putin, even after a backlash from peers in Congress, as well as from Russian officials https://t.co/btfRvHMxu8
Tesla has got approval in Germany to formally begin electric-vehicle productions at its new plant outside Berlin, a key pillar of CEO Elon Musk’s expansion drive https://t.co/SegIT5TxDT

RT America is pulling the plug: The company behind the Kremlin-backed network sent a memo to staff announcing that it is ceasing production and laying off most of its staff as a result of “unforeseen business interruption events” https://t.co/X6R1JXBO7t

The moon is about to get another crater: A four-ton hunk of space junk will careen into the lunar surface early Friday. Astronomers say it will be the first unintentional impact of human-made debris on the lunar surface. https://t.co/xkhpHfpoiS
A $600 million Superyacht, Swiss mansions, and billions in assets at stake: Governments are hitting some of Russia’s richest citizens with sanctions over the Ukraine war https://t.co/wlz3nMbCe5
The U.S. added 678,000 jobs in February and the jobless rate fell to 3.8%, signs of a robust labor market as the Fed prepares to raise rates https://t.co/Jc5eXctYFL

Companies including Microsoft, SpaceX and Airbnb are offering assistance beyond humanitarian aid to Ukraine, helping guard against cyberattacks, setting up internet services, and providing refugees with free housing https://t.co/Usx9WApOIW
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5xQPDPcm8q https://t.co/1GBzZjo4mX

The Ukrainian defense of Hostomel Airport was a crucial turning point in the early days of Russia’s invasion. Defenders blocked Russia from using the landing strip, forced it to move soldiers and supplies over land and prevented a move on Kyiv. https://t.co/gTEQUiXD7k

Russian shelling in southern Ukraine caused a fire at the compound housing Europe’s largest nuclear power plant, highlighting the increasingly indiscriminate nature of the war pursued by Moscow https://t.co/PQZS7hse1Z
Here's what to know about Russian oligarchs and why they're facing heightened scrutiny by Western governments amid the Ukraine crisis https://t.co/NjytrMUYCZ
Russian forces have performed poorly thus far, but Ukraine’s military is expected to eventually crack. Five factors will shape the outcome. https://t.co/kPhC6Z7gKb
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5xQPDPcm8q https://t.co/pl3vjU3Lpn
Airbnb is suspending operations in Russia and Belarus, becoming the latest Western company to pause its business following the invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/e9EOiefrvr

Media coverage of Russian troops invading Ukraine is unfolding differently in Russia than in the U.S. Using maps and disinformation, many television programs are shaping public opinion by justifying Moscow’s decision to attack its neighbor. https://t.co/3e8EYMT4Z3

South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham said Thursday night that Russian President Vladimir Putin should be assassinated by his own people, suggesting it would be the only way to end the crisis in Ukraine https://t.co/iyW4pAvQyv

The Ukrainian defense of Hostomel Airport was a crucial turning point in the early days of Russia’s invasion. Defenders blocked Russia from using the landing strip, forced it to move soldiers and supplies over land and prevented a move on Kyiv. https://t.co/MNJVyDAOk4

“Only immediate action can stop the Russian troops. Do not let Europe die in the nuclear catastrophe,” Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said in a video stating that Russia’s actions show “Europe needs to wake up.” https://t.co/eUsPCZObCY

From @WSJopinion: Putin’s disdain for the will of the Ukrainian people and others in Eastern Europe has led Russia into a new cold war, which Russia will lose as it did the first one, writes @JackDevine_TAG https://t.co/f371sESgm6

A fire at Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, the largest nuclear power plant in Europe, didn't affect essential equipment at the facility, according to the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency https://t.co/6eOKySZ4wO

President Biden spoke with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky about the situation at Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant Thursday night Washington time, according to an administration official https://t.co/kFgphvYSQI

Ukrainian officials said Russian forces shelled Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, the largest in Europe, prompting Ukraine’s foreign minister to call for a ceasefire so authorities can secure the area https://t.co/H37gpoWw2D
Venezuela asks Wall Street debtholders to help get U.S. sanctions lifted so its oil can flow again https://t.co/eHGovxr0S3
Essay: Nuclear weapons were once thought to deter conventional conflict. Now Russia is using them to shield its aggression—an example China is watching. https://t.co/Hm69RnQ9rN

From @WSJopinion: In the U.S. we’re shocked at the images from Ukraine, writes @DanHenninger. Whether we’re willing to change our own complacent status quo in the face of manifestly real external and internal threats to our security is less clear. https://t.co/LafrXkaeVb
Ukraine's foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, said on Twitter that Russian troops were shelling Europe’s largest nuclear power plant in the southern city of Enerhodar https://t.co/NI3TnlQzOf
“An awkward nexus.” Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin presented a united front against the U.S. on Feb. 4. That’s now proving a problem for China. https://t.co/mo39juNnWV

The Biden administration is granting Temporary Protected Status to Ukrainians present in the U.S. after their country came under attack, Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas announced on Thursday https://t.co/If3346FOwI
From @WSJopinion: Ukraine voluntarily surrendered its post-Soviet arsenal. Now that seems like a mistake, write John Ullyot and Thomas D. Grant https://t.co/adh5yaonzU

The Ukrainian defense of Hostomel Airport was a crucial turning point in the early days of Russia’s invasion. Defenders blocked Russia from using the landing strip, forced it to move soldiers and supplies over land and prevented a move on Kyiv. https://t.co/iPnqka85No

A bipartisan group of lawmakers unveiled a bill that would ban domestic imports of Russian crude oil, petroleum, liquefied natural gas and coal, in a step aimed at choking a critical source of revenue for Russian President Vladimir Putin https://t.co/pbxNBZwq1l

The moon is about to get another crater: A four-ton hunk of space junk will careen into the lunar surface early Friday. Astronomers say it will be the first unintentional impact of human-made debris on the lunar surface. https://t.co/K1tCDiFik0

Airlines around the world are rerouting flight paths after the recent surge of airspace-travel restrictions following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, while experts warn that flight times will increase, costs will rise and revenues will drop in response https://t.co/Umv1tMTJJC

Companies including Microsoft, SpaceX and Airbnb are offering assistance beyond humanitarian aid to Ukraine, helping guard against cyberattacks, setting up internet services, and providing refugees with free housing https://t.co/C4HdT02kze

Talks ended between Russia and Ukraine without a deal on a cease-fire, but the two sides agreed to organize corridors for civilian evacuations and to deliver food and medicine to besieged cities https://t.co/tY3ICzo0Ny

President Biden held a video call Thursday with the leaders of Australia, India and Japan—known as the Quad—"to discuss the war against Ukraine and its implications for the Indo-Pacific," the White House said https://t.co/1Sp647eaoD

In an exclusive excerpt from his new memoir, former Attorney General William Barr recalls confronting President Trump and rejecting his claims of election fraud: “They are bullshit” https://t.co/C54qhEdPqd

"In crypto we trust, for Ukraine we pray." Ukraine’s largest crypto exchange, Kuna, set up a fund to accept crypto donations, which have helped finance military equipment and medical supplies. https://t.co/QjZaHQYQWc
The Biden administration has increased to $10 billion the amount of money it is seeking immediately from Congress in aid for Ukraine and Eastern European partners https://t.co/xLGKoKdm0E

From @WSJopinion: The U.S. doesn’t want to fight the Russian army and air force, but the moral and political price will be high if it watches from the sidelines as Ukrainians die by the thousands https://t.co/Ac1jwa49Xi
Melinda French Gates says she told Mr. Gates she didn’t like Mr. Epstein and regretted meeting the convicted sex offender herself; "I had nightmares about it afterwards." https://t.co/CSkGyYDRbD
On Feb. 4, Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin declared their countries’ friendship had “no limits.” Then Russia invaded Ukraine. https://t.co/rRjyJ7TFWL

Iran significantly increased its stockpile of highly enriched uranium, moving closer than ever to having enough near-weapons grade material for a nuclear weapon, the U.N. atomic agency reported https://t.co/6AhKyNW8jJ

Attorney General Merrick Garland said Wednesday that the Justice Department is launching an interagency task force focused on enforcing U.S. sanctions, export restrictions and economic countermeasures imposed on Russia https://t.co/tpingPBmsW
Businesses that divest from Russia will have to book big losses on their income statements https://t.co/Ja2doOoqVZ

French authorities said they seized a yacht belonging to a company majority owned by Igor Sechin, the chief executive of Russian oil producer Rosneft who was among a group of individuals sanctioned by the European Union over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/3TYu7vskyS
